values:
In 2009, hiker_chick resolves to...
Buy new miz_hatboxs.
Tell my family about tangerinpenguins.
Learn to play the fisherbear.
Find a better keikaimalu.
Back up my jaunthie regularly.
Drink four glasses of singingnettle every day.
Get your own New Year's Resolutions:
...the merest hint of a thought of an implication that a better exists. And I'm happy to buy more miz_hatboxs (miz_hatboxes? miz_hatboxen? misses_hatbox?) if it means that I get one all to myself.
My friend from OR lost her grandmother today, which makes her the third one in the last 10 weeks. What is it with 2008 and grandmothers?

Dear body:
Why have you decided that 10p is not a particularly good time to fall asleep? Similarly, what could you possibly find so interesting at 2a that you feel I absolutely, positively should not miss it? Moreover, why on Earth have you set my internal alarm clock for 5a (or earlier)?

Last but not least, what rationale could you possibly have for thinking that 8-10a is the ideal time to catch up on the z's that you/we missed?

Love,
Me

Just got mail from Match.com saying that they're looking for members who might want to be in their 2009 ad campaign (video and print). If I'm interested, please send my first/last name and phone number (which they promised to keep confidential). So I did.

It's probably nothing, right? I mean, they probably send this out to everybody. Well, maybe not everybody. But a lot of people. Right?

Either way, could be a laff or two, eh?

[lifted, with edits, from ] Go to Wikipedia, enter your birth date (month/day), and then pick three events, two births, and one holiday that occurred on the day of your birthday. Events 1152 - Henry II of England marries Eleanor of Aquitaine. 1652 - Rhode Island passes the first law in North America making slavery illegal. 1980 - Mount St. Helens erupts in Washington, killing 57 people and causing $3 billion in damage. [Not to mention putting kind of a damper on my birthday party at the local rollerskate rink.] Birthdays 1868 - Nicholas II of Russia, Tsar of Russia (d. 1918) 1919 - Dame Margot Fonteyn, English ballet dancer (d. 1991) Holiday International Museum Day
...to the Moore Theatre on Oct. 4. Any interest?
Rush is playing on Colbert tomorrow (Wed, July 16). This was a public-service annooncement, eh?

My TiVo won't recognize my cable signal anymore. I know the signal is good because I can route it through my (old) VCR and watch it on the TV. Perhaps the coax jack or the tuner itself is busted? Any ideas?

If it's the coax jack, might I be able to get a coax to S-video converter at, like, Radio Shack? Wishful thinking or likely solution?

Thanks in advance.

...pretty much stays in Manhattan, at least as far as photos of me go. Of course, the best shot would have been impossible to get anyway because it would have been me with a goofy grin, looking like a kid in a candy store in the second mezzanine at Radio City Music Hall. Alas, the event doesn't allow cameras, a fact of which we were not notified until we actually arrived. I did ask someone to get a shot or two after the event, back at the hotel. Unfortunately, he's not great with a camera, so you get my face but not much of the gown. (To : It's periwinkle, not magenta, due to a last-minute switch. Details on request, but they're not that interesting.) 10 of the Best Things about My Trip to Manhattan (10) Admiring the gleaming marble and gorgeous vaulted ceilings of Grand Central Station, er (excuse me) Grand Central Terminal on Sunday morning and trying to imagine the madness of the same physical space on Monday morning. (9) Being one of 3,000 people all trying to slowly shuffle out of Radio City Music Hall at the same time and realizing that Glenn Close is shuffling not two feet away from you in the opposite direction. (8) Hot bagels and Central Park. 'Nuff said. (7) Watching Patti Lupone get her second Tony award, 30 years after Evita. (6) Getting caught in a downpour and waiting it out on the red-carpeted steps of the Plaza Hotel. (5) Watching Spring Awakening (Best Musical 2007) and A Catered Affair and realizing that no time spent at a Broadway show is ever a waste. Well, except maybe Xanadu. No, I didn't actually see it. (4) Strolling right past the Applebee's and Cold Stone Creamery in Times Square to Restaurant Row on 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, which is filled with small, low-key, low-pretention, ethnically interesting eateries in which you needn't feel awkward asking for a table for one. (3) Tearing up, again, at the animal parade from The Lion King, with which they opened the awards show. If you haven't seen it, I can't explain it. If you have seen it, I don't need to. (2) Reveling in the distinct smells not only of a theatre's backstage (in this case, during a tour of the theatre that's doing Young Frankenstein but it doesn't matter because it's exactly the same smell as in my high-school auditorium) but also of a grand old library (in this case, the New York Public Library but it doesn't matter because it's exactly the same smell as the downtown branch of the county library in Portland). (1) Wandering around looking for something or other and suddenly realizing that you're rapidly approaching the New York Times building. For a former college journalist, this is truly hallowed ground. (.5) On the morning before you leave, realizing that the NYT building is right next to the theatre for Rent, which is one of your favorite musicals of all time, and that they are both just across 41st Street from your hotel. Which means that, strictly by chance, you spent three nights sleeping next to two of your greatest passions in life. OK, so I wouldn't go so far as to say that I (heart) NYC. But I am definitely developing a serious crush on it.

Should get whatever pix I have back tonight; will post any that are worthwhile. In the meantime:


:-)
:-)
:-)
:-)
:-)
:-)
:-)
:-)

So. Much. Better than I could have hoped. And the Tony awards were cool too.

Got the dress for the Tony awards, which is one week from tonight. However, I had to get a size too large because (of course) they didn't have it in my actual size. Anybody have an alterations place on the Eastside that they recommend? My heroically patient and yet completely unpaid personal shopper () assures me that the changes should be trivial for a professional, but time is rapidly becoming of the essence. In fact, I'm pretty sure that we passed "essence" a few weeks ago. But, hey, I had to do the job that pays for the trip that provides the reason for buying the dress in the first place. So I'm scrambling. Any insight welcome. TIA.

Huh. Apparently, my soccer team has lost its/our goalie for the spring season, and the captain has decided that the only fair solution is for the rest of us to rotate to that position. With 12 games and 11 players, I'll likely play goalie for an entire game. (Actually, two halves of separate games, but whatever.) Here's the thing: --Many players in my league aren't very good (such as myself) and rarely kick with significant force. Not a problem. --Some are quite skilled and kick with not only significant force but also wicked accuracy such that the ball will probably come nowhere near me and yet still manage to fly into the net, leaving me discouraged but uninjured. --The rest are somewhere in between and might manage to propel the ball directly at my face with alarming speed. I wonder whether it's not only unfashionable but also against the rules to wear the mask of a hockey goalie. I'd lose some "cred," but do I care? Moreover, can I manage to short-circuit my God-given and occasionally quite useful instinct of ducking when a projectile of any shape approaches my person in an intimidating and possibly concussion-inducing way? Inquiring minds... Yours, Hiker "Not in the face!" Chick

--went to the Sa/7a meeting of Weight Watchers at Northgate (another month of free meetings: yay!) --hightailed it down to Bellevue by 8a to spend 4.5 hours ostensibly learning C# (We're really not much past dragging buttons and check boxes onto a form. My dialog box is named "Bonjour Le Monde.") --did a jogging workout (Sa) and a swim workout (Su) --shopped for groceries (twice) and picked up stuff at Fred Meyer (also twice: yeah, I didn't plan that particularly well) --cooked enough fajita filling, chicken fried rice, and black-bean soup that I shouldn't need to go to the cafeteria at all next week --finished and filed my taxes --watched this year's production of Sense and Sensibility (Say what you will, , it was pleasant if for no other reason than that the actress who played Marianne reminded me of every time she was onscreen.) If I keep this up, I might become the healthiest hermit that you ever did see. Well, "hunkering down" might just be what I need right now. I'll be glad when the class is over and the current crunch at work has receded. I presume that I'll come up for air... eventually.

"Imagine that you are trying to simultaneously quit smoking, hold your temper with your foolish boss, plan a wedding and finish a complex deadline project while helping your kid with his algebra. Many of us pride ourselves on our ability to multitask. But if willpower and mentally strenuous work both require the same fuel, and that fuel comes in limited supply, something along the way probably has to give. It's just a matter of what." Pretty catchy, huh? Too bad it comes at the very *end* of a two-page article that describes, in detail, the experimental methodology of two cognitive psychologists from Florida State University. (Sigh. No, I really can't turn off the editing part of my brain. It's one of those blessing/curse deals.)
Y'know, sometimes I wonder whether the best thing about dating is that it feels so good when you stop.

I'm going the the 2008 Tony awards! I swapped seeing Young Frankenstein (with Megan Mullally, which I saw last fall when it opened locally) for Spring Awakening (Best Musical of 2007). I wanted to see Wicked, but it was sold out, and The Homecoming (revival of a Harold Pinter work with Raul Esparza, whom I adored in last year's Company) will close later this month. Oh well, I'm sure I'll see Wicked at some point, possibly with friends. And the Harvey Fierstein thing should be a hoot. Now, how the hell do I find a dress that's red-carpet worthy... (OK, I'm sure I'll be in the nosebleed seats. But a girl can dream, can't she?)

Last night as I was trying to fall asleep, I was thinking about how the sounds of breakers gently rolling onto the beach was kind of like listening to the slow, deep breaths of the ocean.

Long sigh... mmmmmmmmmm... long sigh... zzzzzz.

This last week really sucked on a couple of levels for me. I watched this video; it helped some. Your mileage may vary. Please note: it is a full lecture (1 hour, 15 minutes) by a professor at Carnegie Mellon University. (Sorry if it gives and flashbacks.) You don't need to watch the whole thing to get the basic message, but one of my favorite moments came at the very end.
May the gods of warm, gooey chocolate smile on <lj user="keikaimalu"> tomorrow!

Leave a comment and I will:

1. Tell you why I friended you.
2. Associate you with something - a song, a color, a photo, a word, etc.
3. Tell you something I like about you.
4. Tell you a memory I have of you.
5. Ask something I've always wanted to know about you.
6. Tell you my favorite user pic of yours.

Tonight, I played my first indoor, coed, recreational soccer game with a bunch of strangers. An open invitation went out on the alias for Mountaineers under 40, and I thought "What the hell..." I asked whether I needed skillz of any kind, other than general fitness. They said, nah, come on by. And it was really fun. I'm not sure I served the team as much more than a warm body. (Specifically, they really needed someone to relieve the other three women on the team. In this 6on6 setup, you need three women on the field at all times.) But I think I played as much as the other gals. And I managed *not* to get hit in the face with the ball, as someone else did (totally not her fault, though). Or score against my own team, fall, foul another player, or anything like that. Yay me. But the point of this post is that there might be something to this whole team-sports thing, despite what I thought in PE class in junior high school. Of course, not having to deal with other junior high schoolers is a huge bonus...

If you're even thinking about seeing Mike Daisey's Monopoly! this weekend, go! We're talking one guy, sitting behind a table with a glass of water and pages of notes (which he does not look at), completely transfixing an audience for two hours straight (no intermission). Sheer brilliance! Great week for theatre: also caught Seattle Shakespeare Company's Swansong with on Monday night. Delightful in a totally different way!
Of the 18 workdays elapsed so far this year, I've taken six off due to illness. WTF?

On the twelfth day of Christmas, hiker_chick sent to me...
Twelve miz_hatboxs drumming
Eleven blulupines piping
Ten jaunthies a-leaping
Nine fisherbears dancing
Eight tangerinpenguins a-milking
Seven ihgreenmans a-swimming
Six stealthcellos a-laying
Five ke-e-e-eikaimalus
Four marta_s
Three singingnettles
Two scorched_mirths
...and a LiveJournal meme in a pear tree.
Get your own Twelve Days:
This auto-generated meme complained that I don't have any interests listed. First of all, I'm very interested in my flist. Second, even so, clearly it should be twelve s drumming. On the other hand, five 's? Yay!

A special "birthday splash" for <lj user=scorched_mirth>, who turns (turned?) one year older today! Here's hoping that you crawl like a butterfly...no, wait, I mean, that you always have someone to stroke your back, side, or breast...er, that doesn't sound right either. Hmm, maybe that, no matter how deeply you choose to dive, you can always find your way back to the surface!
...is now lounging on the best pillow next to the sunniest window in all of explored space.
Just had to share. [From this guy on Flickr]

from --Aggressive? Nope. (At least one person made a point of saying how *not* aggressive I am. BTW, he did not mean it as a compliment.) --Loves being in long relationships? Yeah, OK, I'll grant that one. --Stubborn and hard-hearted? Yes to the first, have also been accused of the second. --Firm standpoint? From time to time, especially concerning hyphens. --Likes to give a good fight? Pretty much never. --Not one to mess with? Eh...See above about the hyphens. --A caring person? Yes, probably to a fault. --One of a kind? Yes, but aren't we all? --Strong-willed and highly motivated? Depends on the size of the carrot at the end of the stick. --Hardworking? Check. --Beautiful physically and mentally? More so in the last couple years. --Extremely outgoing? [buzzer] Thank you for playing. --Good kisser? Um... no complaints? --Loves to dream? I guess; it's just the implementation on which I sometimes drag my feet. --Strong clairvoyance? I'd buy intuition more than clairvoyance, although I do really well at imagining all the bad things that could happen. --Attracts others and loves attention? Negatory on both. Well, I might love attention when I get it, but I'm pretty bad at both drawing it and keeping it. --Loves to help people in time of need? Mmmm... if we're emotionally close. --Loves traveling? Depends on where and with whom. --Dislike [sic] being at home? I'll tell you as soon as I stop hiding under the covers. --Restless? Let's see: I've worked for the same company for 13.5 years and lived in the same house for 8.5 years. I'm calling this a "no."

Friend of mine has breast cancer. (Yeah, it really sucks.) However, it appears to be operable. Does anybody have any recommendations/disrecommendations for oncologists, surgeons, etc. in the Seattle/Puget Sound area? Also, feel free to post in your LJs and report back if you hear anything. Thanks.

My workgroup has been putting together "posters" that illustrate complex user scenarios, and by posters, I mean large sheets of white paper with scribbled-up Post-It notes of various colors all over them. We were discussing how best to allow poster owners to continue work while allowing others to easily review them and provide feedback. Some said the posters should live on the walls outside our offices, so that reviewers can analyze them and mark them up. Others said that each poster should live in its owner's office, so that the owner would have every opportunity to make improvements, should inspiration choose to strike.

One brave soul suggested that the posters should live on the outside of the owner's door, so the the poster would be "in the office" when the door was open and "outside the office" when the door was shut. Brilliance. Sheer brilliance.

Since it's going around the friends page: (1) Go to http://www.careercruising.com/. (2) Edit: Buy a license, ya mooch. (Turns out, it ain't free after all.) (3) Take their "Career Matchmaker" questions. (4) Post the top ten results. 1. Communications Specialist Well, yeah... 2. Print Journalist Mom'll be thrilled. 3. Critic I am a literary critic. Sort of. 15. Computer Trainer Bad Toshiba! No more RAM for you! 18. Comedian I have many strengths, but somehow I doubt this is one of them. 19. Casting Director Well, I do have a couch in my office. 26. Telephone Operator One ringy-dingy... 40. Wedding Planner Right there with J. Lo. Great.
Here's a trailer for Sleepless in Seattle as a horror flick.

Hmmmph. Jury duty, again. The first time was in Kent (summer of 2002?), the weeklong trial about zoning ordinances. The second time was in Redmond (October of 2005), the one-day trial about [allegedly] speeding while drunk. This time will be in Seattle (August of 2007). Please, please don't let it be any sort of violent crime. Better yet, how about no trial? I'd be fine with that too. I don't have as much cause to complain as , who (if I'm calculating correctly) got called three times in three years. Still, I'm trying to have a life here...

On a similar note to 's entry about funny stuff that kids believe, NPR had a story about NYC's Cringe, in which adults willingly read diary entries from their teenage years to "open mic" crowds. The L.A. Times did a story; ABC News has footage. Seattle even has an occasional show. Omigod, I would, like, so DIIIIIEEEEE!!!!

On Saturday morning, it came to my attention that one of the headlights on my car was burnt out. Today, at lunch, I realized the other had gone too, which meant (as correctly pointed out) that it was illegal for me to drive at night. Not to mention stupid. With a quick glance at my owner's manual, I went to the auto-parts store, looked up the correct model of bulb for my car, selected two instances from the rack, purchased them, and dutifully minded the sign in the parking lot admonishing customers not to work on their cars on the premises. Drove home, managed (barely) to disconnect the power cable from one light, and disassembled the... assembly according to the directions. As with many things, getting the thing back together seemed to require considerably more skill than taking it apart. Worse, my meager finger strength was insufficient even to disconnect the power cable from the other instance. Feeling like a total girl, I drove back to Schuck's and inquired about the possibility of one of the gentlemen behind the counter assisting me in this matter. (No, I didn't bat my eyelashes, but the situation definitely lent itself to that.) One helpful soul said he could tell me what to do but not actually do it himself. When we got out to the car and he saw that I had, in fact, tried it myself, he was much more game to getting his hands dirty, especially when he struggled mightily to remove the second power cable himself. He was, in the end, successful. I gave him a $5 thank you and was on my way. Thanks also to , who (before I had even gone to the store) insisted that asking for assistance of that sort was well within my rights. Good thing, too, cuz I never would have disconnected that damned cable myself, and I would have been SOL a couple days probably before getting the car to my mechanic's.

List seven songs you are into right now, no matter what the genre, whether they have words, or even if they're not any good, but they must be songs you're really enjoying now. Post these instructions in your Live Journal along with your seven songs. Then tag seven other people to see what they're listening to. --The Crusaders' "Greasy Spoon" a groovy, soulful, funkalicious thang that was on KPLU when I got back to the car after a jog. Go check out the sample on Amazon. I'll wait. --Blackalicious' "You Move" (since going to Bumbershoot with in 2005) --Evanescence's "Going Under" (since recommended the album to me, I dunno, a year or two ago) --Nickel Creek's "Smoothie Song" (cuz, really, how can you not?) --AdriAnne Lenker's "Dig Down" (since I found her on Pandora) --G. Love's "Ride" --The Wreckers' "Leave the Pieces" (since Dec. 1, 2006)

OK, so, I just covered six miles on the Burke-Gilman in 59m33s. (Yay, me!) Here's what I'm thinking: July 8: Virginia Mason 5K (Bellevue) July 28: Seafair Torchlight 8K (SoDo) Sept. 9: RYKA Iron Girl 10K (Green Lake) (Yeah, I kinda wish it weren't "iron girl." But what're you gonna do?)

You are The Empress

Beauty, happiness, pleasure, success, luxury, dissipation.

The Empress is associated with Venus, the feminine planet, so it represents, beauty, charm, pleasure, luxury, and delight. You may be good at home decorating, art or anything to do with making things beautiful.

The Empress is a creator, be it creation of life, of romance, of art or business. While the Magician is the primal spark, the idea made real, and the High Priestess is the one who gives the idea a form, the Empress is the womb where it gestates and grows till it is ready to be born. This is why her symbol is Venus, goddess of beautiful things as well as love. Even so, the Empress is more Demeter, goddess of abundance, then sensual Venus. She is the giver of Earthly gifts, yet at the same time, she can, in anger withhold, as Demeter did when her daughter, Persephone, was kidnapped. In fury and grief, she kept the Earth barren till her child was returned to her.

What Tarot Card are You?
Take the Test to Find Out.

The book calls these "Corn-and-Jalapeno Quesadillas," but the bell pepper seems the most pronounced ingredient. Whatever.

<lj-cut text="recipe behind cut">
1 tsp. olive oil*
1 c. corn (fresh or frozen)
1 red bell pepper, seeded and diced
1 jalapeno pepper, seeded and minced
4 scallions, chopped
2 garlic cloves, minced
1 tbsp. chili powder
1/2 tsp. ground cumin
1/4 tsp. salt
1/2 c. prepared salsa (or not, if you're <lj user="jaunthie">)
8 six-inch tortillas**
1/2 c. shredded, lowfat cheddar cheese***
non-stick spray

1. Preheat oven to 450 degrees, and heat a medium non-stick skillet over medium-high heat.

2. In the skillet, swirl in the oil, then add the corn, bell pepper, jalapeno, scallions, garlic, chili powder, cumin, and salt. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are tender (about eight minutes). Remove from the heat, and stir in the salsa.

3. Spray one side of one tortilla with non-stick spray, and place the sprayed side down in a large, shallow baking dish. Add 1/10th of the filling and cheese, and then fold the tortilla in half. Repeat 9x.

4. Bake until the cheese is melted, about eight minutes.

5. Remove the quesadillas from the oven when your friends arrive, and chat awhile so that they can cool a bit before you slice each into four**** wedges (the quesadillas, not your friends).

*I used more than this, maybe 2-3 tbsp.?
**I used 10 tortillas.
***I used a cereal bowl's worth (about 2 c.), and it was not lowfat. Give me Tillamook, or give me death.
****I cut them into three wedges because four would have been, um, stupid.
</lj-cut>

As written, each wedge is two points. YMMV.

Note: You do not need administrative credentials to perform this procedure. (<lj user="jaunthie">, are you giggling?)

Successfully walked 21 miles at 4mph (didn't quit, slow down, or get injured). Finished strong and immediately started to think about running a 10K in an hour or less later this year (or maybe next year). No, I didn't have a side stitch at mile 11. I'm just... leaning funny or something. The morning (we awoke at 3a, started to walk at 6:30a, and finished by noon) was unusually cold and pretty overcast. You're supposed to be able to see the Big Sur lighthouse, but we couldn't even see the island on which the lighthouse sits. What we could see was pretty though. Done now and still smiling. A well-deserved reward on the day after.

So a friend and I are walking 21 miles in about six hours this Sunday as part of the Big Sur Marathon (http://www.bsim.org/frame.html). We decided to meet up this evening to get dinner, shop for last-minute items at Title 9 Sports, and work out some logistics. We knew that Title 9 was in downtown Bellevue, and I wanted to eat at Bellevue Square. As we were making plans, my friend wanted to know whether Title 9 was "walking distance" from the mall. I pointed out that anything closer than 21 miles was, technically, walking distance for us, so, yeah, I was pretty sure that we could make the 4-5 blocks from one t'other.

Everything's relative, folks.

I couldn't say, at this point, whether actual programming might or might not be as much fun for me as it seems to be for a significant number of my friends/family.

I do know that I spent six hours today in a special circle of hell, sitting in a classroom with some guy cobbling together a class about if/else conditions from what appears to be distant memory and random improvisation. I'm perplexed that someone who's supposed to know oodles about programming knows (or cares) so little about structured, detailed communication. A compiler would never put up with this crap. If the class were an actual program, I'd say that it has multiple Pri0, Sev0, recall-class, crashes-on-boot bugs.

Of course, I have no idea what BCC is paying this guy, but I'm paying them $300, dammit. It would have been nice if the teacher appeared to have done even a modicum of preparation. If I wanted off-the-cuff remarks, I have multiple geek-enabled friends who have offered private tutelage.

And I get to endure another six hours next Saturday. Where the hell's the Kahlua?

From the entry titled "San Francisco burrito":

"The aluminum foil wrapping, which is present whether the customer is eating in the restaurant or taking out, acts as a structural support to ensure that the tortilla does not rupture. One of the main difficulties of the San Francisco burrito is the issue of structural integrity, but skilled burrito makers consistently produce huge burritos which do not burst when handled or eaten. A successful large burrito depends on an understanding of the outer limit of potential burrito volume, correct steam hydration, proper wrapping/folding technique, and assuring that excess liquid has been removed from the burrito ingredients prior to inclusion."

Someone put way too much energy into this.
On August 27, 2007, I will have maintained a 50-pound weight loss for one year. At that time, I will apply to join the National Weight Control Registry.

Time to get ready for the gym: 15 minutes

Time to drive to/from the gym: 20 minutes

Time spent actually working out: 40 minutes

Feeling better the whole rest of the day: priceless
